title: How does Whatsapp deliver messages to the receiver? Does the receiver continuously check for new messages? - Quora

response.answer_text: The receiver’s phone is always connected to the server. There’s a service that always runs in the background which ensures you are connected to their servers all the time, when a network is cut, it will just stay there waiting for you to come back online, once you do you get connected to the server again. Basically how it works is, user A sends a message to user B, it reaches Whatsapp servers, the server checks, is userB connected to me right now? if Yes, send the message to the user’s phone, if no then put it in a queue, when the user reconnects, the server checks if userB’s queue is not empty then pushes all the messages to userB’s phone. Its bidirectional. You might want to read on XMPP, MQTT, you’ll get to understand how they work, there’s also Long polling. Each of these fit based on the application. I choose a queue data structure because I think it’s obvious on messaging applications due to its First In First Out (FIFO) rule, do they use it in memory or use some kinda database idk. You get the idea though.
